Award.AwardTitle: Coherent Multidimensional Spectroscopy of the Oxygen Evolving Complex in Photosystem II
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Measurement and Imaging and the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Programs of the Chemistry Division have funded Professor John C. Wright of the University of Wisconsin to develop laser spectroscopy methods for measuring complex molecular systems with quantum state resolution. The methods are analogous to the brain's ability to distinguish colors from the response of the three types of retinal cone cells. The laser methods use three different laser beam colors to simultaneously excite three quantum states of specific molecules that proceed to drive photosynthesis. The methods provide the key for discovering how plants make oxygen by resolving the quantum states actually involved in photosynthesis.

The primary research goal is applying the new laser methods to understanding the mechanism of oxygen evolution in photosynthesis. Oxygen is created at the oxygen evolution center (OEC) in photosystem II (PS II). The OEC contains Mn, O, and Ca ions and amino acid ligands. The laser beam colors will excite different combinations of vibrational and electronic states of the OEC that distinguish it from the much larger number of molecules in PS II. Different transition metal coordination complexes cobalamin will serve as model systems for testing and developing the methods. The project will resolve the quantum state changes as the OEC progresses through its different oxidation states. The changes will be correlated with those measured by the Biology with X-ray lasers NSF-STC program. The impact of this research is broadened by the participation of under-represented minorities; the development of strategies, materials, and the educational infrastructure required to implement active learning in college classrooms; and the dissemination of the research through different communication channels. The broadest impact is providing a model for how to efficiently collect and use solar energy for our energy future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The “Ten Big Ideas” initiative of the National Science Foundation and the “Directing Matter and Energy: Five Challenges for Science and the Imagination” report of the Department of Energy both recognize the central importance of achieving Quantum Control of Electrons in Atoms, Molecules, and Materials as one of the grand challenges in science. Our research is directly connected with this grand challenge. It has resulted in the development of a new approach to achieving individual quantum state resolution in complex molecules and materials using quantum mechanical superposition states, so-called “Schrodinger cat states”, where the molecules or materials occupy multiple states simultaneously. We call this approach Coherent Multidimensional Spectroscopy (CMDS). Since any quantum state is unique for every molecule or material, the states serve as fingerprints for identifying the molecules or materials. All fields of science measure these fingerprints using modern instruments to characterize samples. The increasing complexity of materials, however, compromises modern methods because the multiplicity of fingerprints from a material’s components obscures each component’s individual fingerprints. The methods we have developed during our grant use tunable lasers to create and measure quantum mechanical Schrodinger cat states containing multiple quantum states. Thus, each molecule has multiple fingerprints defined by its quantum states. Not only does this allow resolution of the individual components, it also provides direct access to the quantum states that control the properties of each component and how each component interacts to define the properties of a material.

 Our CMDS methods are transformative. Their methodology is based on quantum mechanical principles that are ideal for probing complex materials in all fields of science and technology. The work during this grant has developed the technology, extended the theoretical foundations for understanding the multidimensional spectra, and applied the methodology to complex enzymes that control life processes. Vitamin B12 is a co-factor for many enzymatic reactions but the most important are bond cleavage events that control its mechanism of operation. They are not understood. Our CMDS forms Schrodinger cat states containing two vibrational and two electronic quantum states that act like 3-dimensional fingerprints for vitamin B12. We have shown that continuous changes of the 3 lasers allows us to change the Schrodinger cat states to any arbitrary set of the vitamin B12 quantum states. The data from this approach shows how all of the quantum states are connected to each other. We expect that we will be able to watch the enzyme in operation when the vitamin B12 is inserted. Our experiments are feasibility demonstrations of the power of CMDS. Our goal is to disseminate and commercialize CMDS so it becomes available to all fields of science and technology. Dissemination is accelerated by applying the methodology to understand other grand challenges, in particular the challenge of understanding how plants make oxygen. Multielectron oxidation reactions are central to developing new energy technologies and the oxygen evolution center in plants is the most efficient example of these important reactions. It is the next step in our program. Future work on dissemination will involve organic and inorganic synthetic chemists in this methodology so it can guide and enhance synthetic strategies by characterizing the synthetic methods at the most fundamental quantum mechanical level. The field of this new methodology must be broadened beyond its current narrow confines before dissemination can occur more widely.

 Broader Impacts:

The intellectual merit section describes how CMDS is a transformative technology that has implications for all fields of science. Its development and dissemination is also the broadest and most important impact of our work. We use our web site to provide a tutorial that covers the fundamental physical processes underlying CMDS as well as examples of CMDS applications. We have attended national and international conferences to present our CMDS research. The conferences include the International Conference on Coherent Multidimensional Spectroscopy, American Chemical Society national meetings, SciX national meetings, and the Pacifichem 2015 meeting. The P.I. is the Chairman of the International CMDS Conference.

Graduate students in our group are involved in outreach programs to bring our work and science in general to the public, particularly young people. The programs include Do It Yourself (DIY) workshops, Wisconsin IceCube High School Outreach, a 3 day electronics PEOPLE program for people of color and low income students, volunteering for the DOE sponsored Science Bowl and the Wisconsin Science Festival, writing articles in the campus newspaper on research being done at the UW, meeting with autistic children to teach chemistry, presenting chemistry demonstrations at local schools, and tutoring students who are struggling in chemistry. The P.I. continues the development and dissemination of new active teaching methods and materials that enhance the development of skills and scientific competence. These developments are published in Journal of Chemical Education. He participates in the UW Reach and Delta programs to develop and disseminate new instructional methods.
